p: Shift from N-poor to relatively N-rich conditions is a natural repercussion of succession in psammophilous grasslands due to deposition of plant biomass [ 2, 59] which causes gradual development of mineral horizon [ 9]. Organic forms of N are released from reservoir of plant biomass via microbial metabolism [ 52] and mineralized throughout succession of acidic grassland [ 9, 52]. It is worth mentioning that N cycling process in Podzol soils (where mineral forms of N account only 1% of total N [ 60]) is influenced by many physical and chemical soil traits [ 2, 52, 61]. It makes hard to predict quantitative equilibrium between NO 3 ‒ and NH 4 + forms in soil. However, NH 4 + is adsorbed mostly on silt and clay fractions, whilst NO 3 ‒ remains in a soil solution [ 62] thus is better available for plants (e.g. during seed imbibition) but is also more likely to percolate to ground water with precipitation [ 2]. In context of presented results it can be stated that the species persisting in acidic dry grasslands need systematic perturbations uncovering poorer soil layers, free of N depositions.
